title: Fuite d eau en pleine nuit : que faire et pourquoi faire appel à Expresse Dépannage 24h/24 ?
excerpt: Optimiser les performances de votre application React : Les meilleures pratiques
author: Stephane Brunie

body.raw:
Fuite d'eau en pleine nuit: que faire et pourquoi faire appel à Expresse Dépannage ?

Les fuites d'eau sont l'une des urgences domestiques les plus courantes et peuvent survenir à tout moment. Si une fuite se produit en pleine nuit, elle peut rapidement se transformer en cauchemar si elle n'est pas traitée à temps. C’est dans ce genre de situation qu’un service de plomberie disponible 24h/24 comme Expresse Dépannage devient indispensable. Nous intervenons rapidement pour minimiser les dégâts et rétablir votre confort.

1. Les types courants de fuites d'eau nocturnes

Certaines fuites d'eau sont plus fréquentes que d'autres, et savoir les identifier peut vous aider à mieux réagir en attendant l’arrivée des professionnels :

  • Fuites des canalisations sous évier : Elles se produisent souvent à cause de joints usés ou de fissures dans les tuyaux. Bien qu'elles puissent sembler mineures, elles peuvent entraîner des dégâts d'eau importants si elles ne sont pas traitées immédiatement.
  • Fuites de réservoirs de WC : Un dysfonctionnement du mécanisme de chasse d’eau peut provoquer une fuite continue d’eau, gaspillant de l’eau et augmentant votre facture.
  • Fuites de robinet : Cela peut sembler anodin, mais un robinet qui fuit peut gaspiller des litres d’eau chaque jour, en plus de rendre la situation inconfortable si la fuite empire la nuit.
  • Fuites d’eau de chauffe-eau : Une fuite au niveau de votre chauffe-eau peut non seulement endommager votre maison, mais aussi vous priver d'eau chaude.

2. Que faire en attendant l’arrivée du plombier ?

Il y a plusieurs raisons pour lesquelles faire appel à Expresse Dépannage, un service disponible 24h/24 et 7j/7, est la meilleure solution en cas de fuite nocturne :

  • Intervention rapide : Nos techniciens qualifiés se déplacent rapidement, de jour comme de nuit, pour résoudre vos problèmes de plomberie. Nous savons qu’une fuite d’eau ne peut pas attendre, surtout en pleine nuit.
  • Professionnalisme : Nous utilisons des équipements de pointe pour diagnostiquer et réparer efficacement les fuites d'eau, tout en minimisant les dégâts. Nos plombiers sont formés pour intervenir sur tous types d'installations, même les plus complexes.
  • Sécurité : Les fuites d’eau peuvent entraîner des risques pour votre sécurité, notamment en matière d'électricité ou de moisissures. Grâce à notre intervention rapide, nous veillons à ce que votre maison reste un environnement sûr.
  • Économie d’eau et de coûts : Une fuite non réparée peut entraîner une consommation d'eau excessive, augmentant votre facture. En intervenant rapidement, Expresse Dépannage vous aide à économiser sur le long terme.

3. Pourquoi choisir Expresse Dépannage pour une fuite en pleine nuit ?

Il y a plusieurs raisons pour lesquelles faire appel à Expresse Dépannage, un service disponible 24h/24 et 7j/7, est la meilleure solution en cas de fuite nocturne :

  • Intervention rapide : Nos techniciens qualifiés se déplacent rapidement, de jour comme de nuit, pour résoudre vos problèmes de plomberie. Nous savons qu’une fuite d’eau ne peut pas attendre, surtout en pleine nuit.
  • Professionnalisme : Nous utilisons des équipements de pointe pour diagnostiquer et réparer efficacement les fuites d'eau, tout en minimisant les dégâts. Nos plombiers sont formés pour intervenir sur tous types d'installations, même les plus complexes.
  • Sécurité : Les fuites d’eau peuvent entraîner des risques pour votre sécurité, notamment en matière d'électricité ou de moisissures. Grâce à notre intervention rapide, nous veillons à ce que votre maison reste un environnement sûr.
  • Économie d’eau et de coûts : Une fuite non réparée peut entraîner une consommation d'eau excessive, augmentant votre facture. En intervenant rapidement, Expresse Dépannage vous aide à économiser sur le long terme.

Conclusion

Faire face à une fuite d’eau en pleine nuit peut être une situation stressante et urgente. Mais avec Expresse Dépannage, vous pouvez compter sur une équipe réactive et professionnelle prête à intervenir 24h/24, 7j/7. Que ce soit pour une fuite mineure ou une urgence majeure, nous mettons tout en œuvre pour protéger votre habitation et restaurer votre tranquillité.

Si vous avez un problème de fuite d’eau, n'attendez pas : contactez-nous dès maintenant pour une intervention rapide et efficace !

title: article
excerpt: Bien manger,Dormir suffisamment et de manière régulière est aussi important que l'entraînement lui-même pour les athlètes de haut niveau.
author: Andy Ramaroson

body.raw:
Until now, trying to style an article, document, or blog post with Tailwind has been a tedious task that required a keen eye for typography and a lot of complex custom CSS. By default, Tailwind removes all of the default browser styling from paragraphs, headings, lists and more. This ends up being really useful for building application UIs because you spend less time undoing user-agent styles, but when you _really are_ just trying to style some content that came from a rich-text editor in a CMS or a markdown file, it can be surprising and unintuitive. We get lots of complaints about it actually, with people regularly asking us things like: > Why is Tailwind removing the default styles on my `h1` elements? How do I disable this? What do you mean I lose all the other base styles too? > We hear you, but we're not convinced that simply disabling our base styles is what you really want. You don't want to have to remove annoying margins every time you use a `p` element in a piece of your dashboard UI. And I doubt you really want your blog posts to use the user-agent styles either — you want them to look _awesome_, not awful. The `@tailwindcss/typography` plugin is our attempt to give you what you _actually_ want, without any of the downsides of doing something stupid like disabling our base styles. It adds a new `prose` class that you can slap on any block of vanilla HTML content and turn it into a beautiful, well-formatted document: ```html

Garlic bread with cheese: What the science tells us

For years parents have espoused the health benefits of eating garlic bread with cheese to their children, with the food earning such an iconic status in our culture that kids will often dress up as warm, cheesy loaf for Halloween.

But a recent study shows that the celebrated appetizer may be linked to a series of rabies cases springing up around the country.

``` For more information about how to use the plugin and the features it includes, [read the documentation](https://github.com/tailwindcss/typography/blob/master/README.md). --- ## What to expect from here on out What follows from here is just a bunch of absolute nonsense I've written to dogfood the plugin itself. It includes every sensible typographic element I could think of, like **bold text**, unordered lists, ordered lists, code blocks, block quotes, _and even italics_. It's important to cover all of these use cases for a few reasons: 1. We want everything to look good out of the box. 2. Really just the first reason, that's the whole point of the plugin. 3. Here's a third pretend reason though a list with three items looks more realistic than a list with two items. Now we're going to try out another header style. ### Typography should be easy So that's a header for you — with any luck if we've done our job correctly that will look pretty reasonable. Something a wise person once told me about typography is: > Typography is pretty important if you don't want your stuff to look like trash. Make it good then it won't be bad. It's probably important that images look okay here by default as well: Contrary to popular belief, Lorem Ipsum is not simply random text. It has roots in a piece of classical Latin literature from 45 BC, making it over 2000 years old. Now I'm going to show you an example of an unordered list to make sure that looks good, too: - So here is the first item in this list. - In this example we're keeping the items short. - Later, we'll use longer, more complex list items. And that's the end of this section. ## What if we stack headings? ### We should make sure that looks good, too. Sometimes you have headings directly underneath each other. In those cases you often have to undo the top margin on the second heading because it usually looks better for the headings to be closer together than a paragraph followed by a heading should be. ### When a heading comes after a paragraph … When a heading comes after a paragraph, we need a bit more space, like I already mentioned above. Now let's see what a more complex list would look like. - **I often do this thing where list items have headings.** For some reason I think this looks cool which is unfortunate because it's pretty annoying to get the styles right. I often have two or three paragraphs in these list items, too, so the hard part is getting the spacing between the paragraphs, list item heading, and separate list items to all make sense. Pretty tough honestly, you could make a strong argument that you just shouldn't write this way. - **Since this is a list, I need at least two items.** I explained what I'm doing already in the previous list item, but a list wouldn't be a list if it only had one item, and we really want this to look realistic. That's why I've added this second list item so I actually have something to look at when writing the styles. - **It's not a bad idea to add a third item either.** I think it probably would've been fine to just use two items but three is definitely not worse, and since I seem to be having no trouble making up arbitrary things to type, I might as well include it. After this sort of list I usually have a closing statement or paragraph, because it kinda looks weird jumping right to a heading. ## Code should look okay by default. I think most people are going to use [highlight.js](https://highlightjs.org/) or [Prism](https://prismjs.com/) or something if they want to style their code blocks but it wouldn't hurt to make them look _okay_ out of the box, even with no syntax highlighting. Here's what a default `tailwind.config.js` file looks like at the time of writing: ```js module.exports = { purge: [], theme: { extend: {}, }, variants: {}, plugins: [], } ``` Hopefully that looks good enough to you. ### What about nested lists? Nested lists basically always look bad which is why editors like Medium don't even let you do it, but I guess since some of you goofballs are going to do it we have to carry the burden of at least making it work. 1. **Nested lists are rarely a good idea.** - You might feel like you are being really "organized" or something but you are just creating a gross shape on the screen that is hard to read. - Nested navigation in UIs is a bad idea too, keep things as flat as possible. - Nesting tons of folders in your source code is also not helpful. 2. **Since we need to have more items, here's another one.** - I'm not sure if we'll bother styling more than two levels deep. - Two is already too much, three is guaranteed to be a bad idea. - If you nest four levels deep you belong in prison. 3. **Two items isn't really a list, three is good though.** - Again please don't nest lists if you want people to actually read your content. - Nobody wants to look at this. - I'm upset that we even have to bother styling this. The most annoying thing about lists in Markdown is that `
  • ` elements aren't given a child `

    ` tag unless there are multiple paragraphs in the list item. That means I have to worry about styling that annoying situation too. - **For example, here's another nested list.** But this time with a second paragraph. - These list items won't have `

    ` tags - Because they are only one line each - **But in this second top-level list item, they will.** This is especially annoying because of the spacing on this paragraph. - As you can see here, because I've added a second line, this list item now has a `

    ` tag. This is the second line I'm talking about by the way. - Finally here's another list item so it's more like a list. - A closing list item, but with no nested list, because why not? And finally a sentence to close off this section. ## There are other elements we need to style I almost forgot to mention links, like [this link to the Tailwind CSS website](https://tailwindcss.com). We almost made them blue but that's so yesterday, so we went with dark gray, feels edgier. We even included table styles, check it out: We also need to make sure inline code looks good, like if I wanted to talk about `` elements or tell you the good news about `@tailwindcss/typography`. ### Sometimes I even use `code` in headings Even though it's probably a bad idea, and historically I've had a hard time making it look good. This _"wrap the code blocks in backticks"_ trick works pretty well though really. Another thing I've done in the past is put a `code` tag inside of a link, like if I wanted to tell you about the [`tailwindcss/docs`](https://github.com/tailwindcss/docs) repository. I don't love that there is an underline below the backticks but it is absolutely not worth the madness it would require to avoid it. #### We haven't used an `h4` yet But now we have. Please don't use `h5` or `h6` in your content, Medium only supports two heading levels for a reason, you animals. I honestly considered using a `before` pseudo-element to scream at you if you use an `h5` or `h6`. We don't style them at all out of the box because `h4` elements are already so small that they are the same size as the body copy. What are we supposed to do with an `h5`, make it _smaller_ than the body copy? No thanks. ### We still need to think about stacked headings though. #### Let's make sure we don't screw that up with `h4` elements, either. Phew, with any luck we have styled the headings above this text and they look pretty good. Let's add a closing paragraph here so things end with a decently sized block of text. I can't explain why I want things to end that way but I have to assume it's because I think things will look weird or unbalanced if there is a heading too close to the end of the document. What I've written here is probably long enough, but adding this final sentence can't hurt. ## GitHub Flavored Markdown I've also added support for GitHub Flavored Mardown using `remark-gfm`. With `remark-gfm`, we get a few extra features in our markdown. Example: autolink literals. A link like www.example.com or https://example.com would automatically be converted into an `a` tag. This works for email links too: contact@example.com.

Garlic bread with cheese: What the science tells us

For years parents have espoused the health benefits of eating garlic bread with cheese to their children, with the food earning such an iconic status in our culture that kids will often dress up as warm, cheesy loaf for Halloween.

But a recent study shows that the celebrated appetizer may be linked to a series of rabies cases springing up around the country.

title: Les solutions pour déboucher vos canalisations
excerpt: Solutions efficaces pour déboucher vos canalisations, interventions professionnelles pour éviter les mauvaises odeurs et les remontées d’eau.
author: Stephane Brunie

body.raw:
Les solutions pour déboucher vos canalisations : astuces et conseils

Les canalisations de nos maisons, qu'il s'agisse de la cuisine, de la salle de bain ou des WC, sont essentielles pour évacuer les eaux usées. Cependant, il suffit d’un bouchon pour perturber leur fonctionnement et créer des problèmes désagréables comme des mauvaises odeurs, des remontées d'eau, ou encore une évacuation ralentie.

Dans cet article, découvrez les meilleures solutions pour déboucher vos canalisations et éviter ces désagréments, ainsi que des conseils pour prévenir de futures obstructions.

Pourquoi faire appel à un professionnel pour déboucher vos canalisations ?

Si vos canalisations sont sévèrement obstruées, faire appel à un expert est souvent la solution la plus efficace. Expresse Dépannage intervient 24h/24 et 7j/7 pour débloquer vos canalisations et résoudre rapidement tout problème, même en cas de bouchons tenaces. Nos techniciens possèdent l’équipement nécessaire pour détecter et résoudre le problème sans endommager votre installation.

Quels sont les risques d'une canalisation bouchée ?

Un bouchon dans vos canalisations peut entraîner de nombreux désagréments :

  • Mauvaises odeurs : L'accumulation de débris peut dégager des odeurs désagréables, surtout dans les salles de bain et la cuisine.
  • Remontées d’eau : Lorsque l'eau ne s'écoule plus correctement, elle peut remonter, provoquant des inondations et des dégâts d'eau.
  • Eau stagnante : Une eau stagnante dans les éviers ou les douches devient un nid à bactéries et peut rapidement créer un environnement insalubre.

Ces problèmes peuvent être aggravés dans les immeubles, où les canalisations communes augmentent le risque de remontées d’eau.

Quels produits utiliser pour déboucher vos canalisations ?

Divers produits, qu'ils soient chimiques ou naturels, peuvent être utilisés pour déboucher vos canalisations. Voici quelques méthodes couramment utilisées :

  • Ventouse : Outil traditionnel pour déboucher un évier ou une douche. Il suffit d'ajouter un peu d'eau, de poser la ventouse sur l'orifice, et de pomper.
  • Démonter le siphon : Cette méthode consiste à dévisser et à nettoyer le siphon pour retirer les débris accumulés.
  • Produits chimiques : Disponibles en magasin, ces produits sont puissants, mais doivent être utilisés avec précaution pour ne pas endommager vos canalisations ou l’environnement.

Solutions naturelles pour déboucher vos canalisations

Si vous souhaitez éviter les produits chimiques, plusieurs solutions naturelles peuvent déboucher efficacement vos canalisations :

  • Bicarbonate de soude et vinaigre blanc : Ce mélange simple est souvent très efficace pour dissoudre les bouchons.
  • Cristaux de soude : Idéaux pour décomposer les matières grasses qui se sont accumulées.
  • Marc de café : Utilisé régulièrement, il aide à prévenir les obstructions tout en neutralisant les odeurs.

Ces alternatives naturelles sont plus respectueuses de l’environnement et parfaites pour les petits bouchons.

Comment éviter les bouchons dans vos canalisations ?

La meilleure façon d’éviter les bouchons est d'adopter quelques bonnes pratiques :

  • Évitez de jeter des objets inappropriés : Lingettes, huiles, tampons, et autres déchets non biodégradables doivent être jetés à la poubelle, pas dans vos canalisations.
  • Nettoyez régulièrement vos canalisations : Un entretien préventif avec des produits naturels ou un simple démontage du siphon permet de maintenir vos canalisations en bon état.
  • Retirez les cheveux régulièrement : Dans la salle de bain, les cheveux sont la principale cause d’obstruction. Prenez l'habitude de les enlever après chaque douche.

Conclusion

Déboucher une canalisation peut être simple si l'on intervient à temps et avec les bons outils. Cependant, pour des bouchons plus complexes, l'intervention d’un professionnel comme Expresse Dépannage est indispensable. Nous sommes à votre disposition 24h/24 et 7j/7 pour toute urgence de plomberie. Pensez à entretenir vos canalisations régulièrement pour éviter les problèmes à long terme.

title: NextJs c'est quoi!
excerpt: Dormir suffisamment et de manière régulière est aussi important que l'entraînement lui-même pour les athlètes de haut niveau.
author: Andy Ramaroson

body.raw:
Next.js : Le Framework React pour la Production

Until now, trying to style an article, document, or blog post with Tailwind has been a tedious task that required a keen eye for typography and a lot of complex custom CSS. By default, Tailwind removes all of the default browser styling from paragraphs, headings, lists and more. This ends up being really useful for building application UIs because you spend less time undoing user-agent styles, but when you _really are_ just trying to style some content that came from a rich-text editor in a CMS or a markdown file, it can be surprising and unintuitive. We get lots of complaints about it actually, with people regularly asking us things like: > Why is Tailwind removing the default styles on my `h1` elements? How do I disable this? What do you mean I lose all the other base styles too? > We hear you, but we're not convinced that simply disabling our base styles is what you really want. You don't want to have to remove annoying margins every time you use a `p` element in a piece of your dashboard UI. And I doubt you really want your blog posts to use the user-agent styles either — you want them to look _awesome_, not awful. The `@tailwindcss/typography` plugin is our attempt to give you what you _actually_ want, without any of the downsides of doing something stupid like disabling our base styles. It adds a new `prose` class that you can slap on any block of vanilla HTML content and turn it into a beautiful, well-formatted document: ```html

Garlic bread with cheese: What the science tells us

For years parents have espoused the health benefits of eating garlic bread with cheese to their children, with the food earning such an iconic status in our culture that kids will often dress up as warm, cheesy loaf for Halloween.

But a recent study shows that the celebrated appetizer may be linked to a series of rabies cases springing up around the country.

``` For more information about how to use the plugin and the features it includes, [read the documentation](https://github.com/tailwindcss/typography/blob/master/README.md). --- ## What to expect from here on out What follows from here is just a bunch of absolute nonsense I've written to dogfood the plugin itself. It includes every sensible typographic element I could think of, like **bold text**, unordered lists, ordered lists, code blocks, block quotes, _and even italics_. It's important to cover all of these use cases for a few reasons: 1. We want everything to look good out of the box. 2. Really just the first reason, that's the whole point of the plugin. 3. Here's a third pretend reason though a list with three items looks more realistic than a list with two items. Now we're going to try out another header style. ### Typography should be easy So that's a header for you — with any luck if we've done our job correctly that will look pretty reasonable. Something a wise person once told me about typography is: > Typography is pretty important if you don't want your stuff to look like trash. Make it good then it won't be bad. It's probably important that images look okay here by default as well: Contrary to popular belief, Lorem Ipsum is not simply random text. It has roots in a piece of classical Latin literature from 45 BC, making it over 2000 years old. Now I'm going to show you an example of an unordered list to make sure that looks good, too: - So here is the first item in this list. - In this example we're keeping the items short. - Later, we'll use longer, more complex list items. And that's the end of this section. ## What if we stack headings? ### We should make sure that looks good, too. Sometimes you have headings directly underneath each other. In those cases you often have to undo the top margin on the second heading because it usually looks better for the headings to be closer together than a paragraph followed by a heading should be. ### When a heading comes after a paragraph … When a heading comes after a paragraph, we need a bit more space, like I already mentioned above. Now let's see what a more complex list would look like. - **I often do this thing where list items have headings.** For some reason I think this looks cool which is unfortunate because it's pretty annoying to get the styles right. I often have two or three paragraphs in these list items, too, so the hard part is getting the spacing between the paragraphs, list item heading, and separate list items to all make sense. Pretty tough honestly, you could make a strong argument that you just shouldn't write this way. - **Since this is a list, I need at least two items.** I explained what I'm doing already in the previous list item, but a list wouldn't be a list if it only had one item, and we really want this to look realistic. That's why I've added this second list item so I actually have something to look at when writing the styles. - **It's not a bad idea to add a third item either.** I think it probably would've been fine to just use two items but three is definitely not worse, and since I seem to be having no trouble making up arbitrary things to type, I might as well include it. After this sort of list I usually have a closing statement or paragraph, because it kinda looks weird jumping right to a heading. ## Code should look okay by default. I think most people are going to use [highlight.js](https://highlightjs.org/) or [Prism](https://prismjs.com/) or something if they want to style their code blocks but it wouldn't hurt to make them look _okay_ out of the box, even with no syntax highlighting. Here's what a default `tailwind.config.js` file looks like at the time of writing: ```js module.exports = { purge: [], theme: { extend: {}, }, variants: {}, plugins: [], } ``` Hopefully that looks good enough to you. ### What about nested lists? Nested lists basically always look bad which is why editors like Medium don't even let you do it, but I guess since some of you goofballs are going to do it we have to carry the burden of at least making it work. 1. **Nested lists are rarely a good idea.** - You might feel like you are being really "organized" or something but you are just creating a gross shape on the screen that is hard to read. - Nested navigation in UIs is a bad idea too, keep things as flat as possible. - Nesting tons of folders in your source code is also not helpful. 2. **Since we need to have more items, here's another one.** - I'm not sure if we'll bother styling more than two levels deep. - Two is already too much, three is guaranteed to be a bad idea. - If you nest four levels deep you belong in prison. 3. **Two items isn't really a list, three is good though.** - Again please don't nest lists if you want people to actually read your content. - Nobody wants to look at this. - I'm upset that we even have to bother styling this. The most annoying thing about lists in Markdown is that `
  • ` elements aren't given a child `

    ` tag unless there are multiple paragraphs in the list item. That means I have to worry about styling that annoying situation too. - **For example, here's another nested list.** But this time with a second paragraph. - These list items won't have `

    ` tags - Because they are only one line each - **But in this second top-level list item, they will.** This is especially annoying because of the spacing on this paragraph. - As you can see here, because I've added a second line, this list item now has a `

    ` tag. This is the second line I'm talking about by the way. - Finally here's another list item so it's more like a list. - A closing list item, but with no nested list, because why not? And finally a sentence to close off this section. ## There are other elements we need to style I almost forgot to mention links, like [this link to the Tailwind CSS website](https://tailwindcss.com). We almost made them blue but that's so yesterday, so we went with dark gray, feels edgier. We even included table styles, check it out: We also need to make sure inline code looks good, like if I wanted to talk about `` elements or tell you the good news about `@tailwindcss/typography`. ### Sometimes I even use `code` in headings Even though it's probably a bad idea, and historically I've had a hard time making it look good. This _"wrap the code blocks in backticks"_ trick works pretty well though really. Another thing I've done in the past is put a `code` tag inside of a link, like if I wanted to tell you about the [`tailwindcss/docs`](https://github.com/tailwindcss/docs) repository. I don't love that there is an underline below the backticks but it is absolutely not worth the madness it would require to avoid it. #### We haven't used an `h4` yet But now we have. Please don't use `h5` or `h6` in your content, Medium only supports two heading levels for a reason, you animals. I honestly considered using a `before` pseudo-element to scream at you if you use an `h5` or `h6`. We don't style them at all out of the box because `h4` elements are already so small that they are the same size as the body copy. What are we supposed to do with an `h5`, make it _smaller_ than the body copy? No thanks. ### We still need to think about stacked headings though. #### Let's make sure we don't screw that up with `h4` elements, either. Phew, with any luck we have styled the headings above this text and they look pretty good. Let's add a closing paragraph here so things end with a decently sized block of text. I can't explain why I want things to end that way but I have to assume it's because I think things will look weird or unbalanced if there is a heading too close to the end of the document. What I've written here is probably long enough, but adding this final sentence can't hurt. ## GitHub Flavored Markdown I've also added support for GitHub Flavored Mardown using `remark-gfm`. With `remark-gfm`, we get a few extra features in our markdown. Example: autolink literals. A link like www.example.com or https://example.com would automatically be converted into an `a` tag. This works for email links too: contact@example.com.

`,(0,t.jsxDEV)(n.pre,{children:(0,t.jsxDEV)(n.code,{className:"language-html",children:`

Garlic bread with cheese: What the science tells us

For years parents have espoused the health benefits of eating garlic bread with cheese to their children, with the food earning such an iconic status in our culture that kids will often dress up as warm, cheesy loaf for Halloween.

But a recent study shows that the celebrated appetizer may be linked to a series of rabies cases springing up around the country.

title: Panne de chauffe-eau: Les étapes à suivre en cas d'urgence !
excerpt: Les pannes de chauffe-eau peuvent être particulièrement pénibles, surtout si elles surviennent en hiver ou au moment où vous en avez le plus besoin.
author: Stephane Brunie

body.raw:
Panne de chauffe-eau : Les étapes à suivre en cas d'urgence

Rien de plus désagréable qu’une panne de chauffe-eau, surtout lorsqu'elle survient à un moment critique. Vous voilà sans eau chaude, ce qui peut rapidement perturber votre quotidien. Face à une telle situation, il est important de savoir comment réagir avant de faire appel à un professionnel comme Expresse Dépannage, disponible 24h/24 et 7j/7 pour vous dépanner.

Les pannes de chauffe-eau peuvent être particulièrement pénibles, surtout si elles surviennent en hiver ou au moment où vous en avez le plus besoin. Cet article vous guidera à travers les étapes à suivre lorsque votre chauffe-eau tombe en panne, et vous montrera pourquoi il est essentiel de faire appel à Expresse Dépannage en urgence.

1. Comment reconnaître une panne de chauffe-eau ?

Il existe plusieurs signes révélateurs d’une panne de chauffe-eau, et les identifier rapidement peut vous aider à minimiser les désagréments :

  • Fuites des canalisations sous évier : Elles se produisent souvent à cause de joints usés ou de fissures dans les tuyaux. Bien qu'elles puissent sembler mineures, elles peuvent entraîner des dégâts d'eau importants si elles ne sont pas traitées immédiatement.
  • Fuites de réservoirs de WC : Un dysfonctionnement du mécanisme de chasse d’eau peut provoquer une fuite continue d’eau, gaspillant de l’eau et augmentant votre facture.
  • Fuites de robinet : Cela peut sembler anodin, mais un robinet qui fuit peut gaspiller des litres d’eau chaque jour, en plus de rendre la situation inconfortable si la fuite empire la nuit.
  • Fuites d’eau de chauffe-eau : Une fuite au niveau de votre chauffe-eau peut non seulement endommager votre maison, mais aussi vous priver d'eau chaude.

2. Que faire en attendant l’arrivée du plombier ?

Il y a plusieurs raisons pour lesquelles faire appel à Expresse Dépannage, un service disponible 24h/24 et 7j/7, est la meilleure solution en cas de fuite nocturne :

  • Intervention rapide : Nos techniciens qualifiés se déplacent rapidement, de jour comme de nuit, pour résoudre vos problèmes de plomberie. Nous savons qu’une fuite d’eau ne peut pas attendre, surtout en pleine nuit.
  • Professionnalisme : Nous utilisons des équipements de pointe pour diagnostiquer et réparer efficacement les fuites d'eau, tout en minimisant les dégâts. Nos plombiers sont formés pour intervenir sur tous types d'installations, même les plus complexes.
  • Sécurité : Les fuites d’eau peuvent entraîner des risques pour votre sécurité, notamment en matière d'électricité ou de moisissures. Grâce à notre intervention rapide, nous veillons à ce que votre maison reste un environnement sûr.
  • Économie d’eau et de coûts : Une fuite non réparée peut entraîner une consommation d'eau excessive, augmentant votre facture. En intervenant rapidement, Expresse Dépannage vous aide à économiser sur le long terme.

3. Pourquoi choisir Expresse Dépannage pour une fuite en pleine nuit ?

Il y a plusieurs raisons pour lesquelles faire appel à Expresse Dépannage, un service disponible 24h/24 et 7j/7, est la meilleure solution en cas de fuite nocturne :

  • Intervention rapide : Nos techniciens qualifiés se déplacent rapidement, de jour comme de nuit, pour résoudre vos problèmes de plomberie. Nous savons qu’une fuite d’eau ne peut pas attendre, surtout en pleine nuit.
  • Professionnalisme : Nous utilisons des équipements de pointe pour diagnostiquer et réparer efficacement les fuites d'eau, tout en minimisant les dégâts. Nos plombiers sont formés pour intervenir sur tous types d'installations, même les plus complexes.
  • Sécurité : Les fuites d’eau peuvent entraîner des risques pour votre sécurité, notamment en matière d'électricité ou de moisissures. Grâce à notre intervention rapide, nous veillons à ce que votre maison reste un environnement sûr.
  • Économie d’eau et de coûts : Une fuite non réparée peut entraîner une consommation d'eau excessive, augmentant votre facture. En intervenant rapidement, Expresse Dépannage vous aide à économiser sur le long terme.

Conclusion

Faire face à une fuite d’eau en pleine nuit peut être une situation stressante et urgente. Mais avec Expresse Dépannage, vous pouvez compter sur une équipe réactive et professionnelle prête à intervenir 24h/24, 7j/7. Que ce soit pour une fuite mineure ou une urgence majeure, nous mettons tout en œuvre pour protéger votre habitation et restaurer votre tranquillité.

Si vous avez un problème de fuite d’eau, n'attendez pas : contactez-nous dès maintenant pour une intervention rapide et efficace !

author: Andy Ramaroson

body.raw:
Until now, trying to style an article, document, or blog post with Tailwind has been a tedious task that required a keen eye for typography and a lot of complex custom CSS. By default, Tailwind removes all of the default browser styling from paragraphs, headings, lists and more. This ends up being really useful for building application UIs because you spend less time undoing user-agent styles, but when you _really are_ just trying to style some content that came from a rich-text editor in a CMS or a markdown file, it can be surprising and unintuitive. We get lots of complaints about it actually, with people regularly asking us things like: > Why is Tailwind removing the default styles on my `h1` elements? How do I disable this? What do you mean I lose all the other base styles too? > We hear you, but we're not convinced that simply disabling our base styles is what you really want. You don't want to have to remove annoying margins every time you use a `p` element in a piece of your dashboard UI. And I doubt you really want your blog posts to use the user-agent styles either — you want them to look _awesome_, not awful. The `@tailwindcss/typography` plugin is our attempt to give you what you _actually_ want, without any of the downsides of doing something stupid like disabling our base styles. It adds a new `prose` class that you can slap on any block of vanilla HTML content and turn it into a beautiful, well-formatted document: ```html

Garlic bread with cheese: What the science tells us

For years parents have espoused the health benefits of eating garlic bread with cheese to their children, with the food earning such an iconic status in our culture that kids will often dress up as warm, cheesy loaf for Halloween.

But a recent study shows that the celebrated appetizer may be linked to a series of rabies cases springing up around the country.

``` For more information about how to use the plugin and the features it includes, [read the documentation](https://github.com/tailwindcss/typography/blob/master/README.md). --- ## What to expect from here on out What follows from here is just a bunch of absolute nonsense I've written to dogfood the plugin itself. It includes every sensible typographic element I could think of, like **bold text**, unordered lists, ordered lists, code blocks, block quotes, _and even italics_. It's important to cover all of these use cases for a few reasons: 1. We want everything to look good out of the box. 2. Really just the first reason, that's the whole point of the plugin. 3. Here's a third pretend reason though a list with three items looks more realistic than a list with two items. Now we're going to try out another header style. ### Typography should be easy So that's a header for you — with any luck if we've done our job correctly that will look pretty reasonable. Something a wise person once told me about typography is: > Typography is pretty important if you don't want your stuff to look like trash. Make it good then it won't be bad. It's probably important that images look okay here by default as well: Contrary to popular belief, Lorem Ipsum is not simply random text. It has roots in a piece of classical Latin literature from 45 BC, making it over 2000 years old. Now I'm going to show you an example of an unordered list to make sure that looks good, too: - So here is the first item in this list. - In this example we're keeping the items short. - Later, we'll use longer, more complex list items. And that's the end of this section. ## What if we stack headings? ### We should make sure that looks good, too. Sometimes you have headings directly underneath each other. In those cases you often have to undo the top margin on the second heading because it usually looks better for the headings to be closer together than a paragraph followed by a heading should be. ### When a heading comes after a paragraph … When a heading comes after a paragraph, we need a bit more space, like I already mentioned above. Now let's see what a more complex list would look like. - **I often do this thing where list items have headings.** For some reason I think this looks cool which is unfortunate because it's pretty annoying to get the styles right. I often have two or three paragraphs in these list items, too, so the hard part is getting the spacing between the paragraphs, list item heading, and separate list items to all make sense. Pretty tough honestly, you could make a strong argument that you just shouldn't write this way. - **Since this is a list, I need at least two items.** I explained what I'm doing already in the previous list item, but a list wouldn't be a list if it only had one item, and we really want this to look realistic. That's why I've added this second list item so I actually have something to look at when writing the styles. - **It's not a bad idea to add a third item either.** I think it probably would've been fine to just use two items but three is definitely not worse, and since I seem to be having no trouble making up arbitrary things to type, I might as well include it. After this sort of list I usually have a closing statement or paragraph, because it kinda looks weird jumping right to a heading. ## Code should look okay by default. I think most people are going to use [highlight.js](https://highlightjs.org/) or [Prism](https://prismjs.com/) or something if they want to style their code blocks but it wouldn't hurt to make them look _okay_ out of the box, even with no syntax highlighting. Here's what a default `tailwind.config.js` file looks like at the time of writing: ```js module.exports = { purge: [], theme: { extend: {}, }, variants: {}, plugins: [], } ``` Hopefully that looks good enough to you. ### What about nested lists? Nested lists basically always look bad which is why editors like Medium don't even let you do it, but I guess since some of you goofballs are going to do it we have to carry the burden of at least making it work. 1. **Nested lists are rarely a good idea.** - You might feel like you are being really "organized" or something but you are just creating a gross shape on the screen that is hard to read. - Nested navigation in UIs is a bad idea too, keep things as flat as possible. - Nesting tons of folders in your source code is also not helpful. 2. **Since we need to have more items, here's another one.** - I'm not sure if we'll bother styling more than two levels deep. - Two is already too much, three is guaranteed to be a bad idea. - If you nest four levels deep you belong in prison. 3. **Two items isn't really a list, three is good though.** - Again please don't nest lists if you want people to actually read your content. - Nobody wants to look at this. - I'm upset that we even have to bother styling this. The most annoying thing about lists in Markdown is that `
  • ` elements aren't given a child `

    ` tag unless there are multiple paragraphs in the list item. That means I have to worry about styling that annoying situation too. - **For example, here's another nested list.** But this time with a second paragraph. - These list items won't have `

    ` tags - Because they are only one line each - **But in this second top-level list item, they will.** This is especially annoying because of the spacing on this paragraph. - As you can see here, because I've added a second line, this list item now has a `

    ` tag. This is the second line I'm talking about by the way. - Finally here's another list item so it's more like a list. - A closing list item, but with no nested list, because why not? And finally a sentence to close off this section. ## There are other elements we need to style I almost forgot to mention links, like [this link to the Tailwind CSS website](https://tailwindcss.com). We almost made them blue but that's so yesterday, so we went with dark gray, feels edgier. We even included table styles, check it out: We also need to make sure inline code looks good, like if I wanted to talk about `` elements or tell you the good news about `@tailwindcss/typography`. ### Sometimes I even use `code` in headings Even though it's probably a bad idea, and historically I've had a hard time making it look good. This _"wrap the code blocks in backticks"_ trick works pretty well though really. Another thing I've done in the past is put a `code` tag inside of a link, like if I wanted to tell you about the [`tailwindcss/docs`](https://github.com/tailwindcss/docs) repository. I don't love that there is an underline below the backticks but it is absolutely not worth the madness it would require to avoid it. #### We haven't used an `h4` yet But now we have. Please don't use `h5` or `h6` in your content, Medium only supports two heading levels for a reason, you animals. I honestly considered using a `before` pseudo-element to scream at you if you use an `h5` or `h6`. We don't style them at all out of the box because `h4` elements are already so small that they are the same size as the body copy. What are we supposed to do with an `h5`, make it _smaller_ than the body copy? No thanks. ### We still need to think about stacked headings though. #### Let's make sure we don't screw that up with `h4` elements, either. Phew, with any luck we have styled the headings above this text and they look pretty good. Let's add a closing paragraph here so things end with a decently sized block of text. I can't explain why I want things to end that way but I have to assume it's because I think things will look weird or unbalanced if there is a heading too close to the end of the document. What I've written here is probably long enough, but adding this final sentence can't hurt. ## GitHub Flavored Markdown I've also added support for GitHub Flavored Mardown using `remark-gfm`. With `remark-gfm`, we get a few extra features in our markdown. Example: autolink literals. A link like www.example.com or https://example.com would automatically be converted into an `a` tag. This works for email links too: contact@example.com.

`,(0,t.jsxDEV)(n.pre,{children:(0,t.jsxDEV)(n.code,{className:"language-html",children:`

Garlic bread with cheese: What the science tells us

For years parents have espoused the health benefits of eating garlic bread with cheese to their children, with the food earning such an iconic status in our culture that kids will often dress up as warm, cheesy loaf for Halloween.

But a recent study shows that the celebrated appetizer may be linked to a series of rabies cases springing up around the country.

title: article 4
excerpt: How to deploy your Next.js apps on Vercel
author: Andy Ramaroson

body.raw:
Until now, trying to style an article, document, or blog post with Tailwind has been a tedious task that required a keen eye for typography and a lot of complex custom CSS. By default, Tailwind removes all of the default browser styling from paragraphs, headings, lists and more. This ends up being really useful for building application UIs because you spend less time undoing user-agent styles, but when you _really are_ just trying to style some content that came from a rich-text editor in a CMS or a markdown file, it can be surprising and unintuitive. We get lots of complaints about it actually, with people regularly asking us things like: > Why is Tailwind removing the default styles on my `h1` elements? How do I disable this? What do you mean I lose all the other base styles too? > We hear you, but we're not convinced that simply disabling our base styles is what you really want. You don't want to have to remove annoying margins every time you use a `p` element in a piece of your dashboard UI. And I doubt you really want your blog posts to use the user-agent styles either — you want them to look _awesome_, not awful. The `@tailwindcss/typography` plugin is our attempt to give you what you _actually_ want, without any of the downsides of doing something stupid like disabling our base styles. It adds a new `prose` class that you can slap on any block of vanilla HTML content and turn it into a beautiful, well-formatted document: ```html

Garlic bread with cheese: What the science tells us

For years parents have espoused the health benefits of eating garlic bread with cheese to their children, with the food earning such an iconic status in our culture that kids will often dress up as warm, cheesy loaf for Halloween.

But a recent study shows that the celebrated appetizer may be linked to a series of rabies cases springing up around the country.

``` For more information about how to use the plugin and the features it includes, [read the documentation](https://github.com/tailwindcss/typography/blob/master/README.md). --- ## What to expect from here on out What follows from here is just a bunch of absolute nonsense I've written to dogfood the plugin itself. It includes every sensible typographic element I could think of, like **bold text**, unordered lists, ordered lists, code blocks, block quotes, _and even italics_. It's important to cover all of these use cases for a few reasons: 1. We want everything to look good out of the box. 2. Really just the first reason, that's the whole point of the plugin. 3. Here's a third pretend reason though a list with three items looks more realistic than a list with two items. Now we're going to try out another header style. ### Typography should be easy So that's a header for you — with any luck if we've done our job correctly that will look pretty reasonable. Something a wise person once told me about typography is: > Typography is pretty important if you don't want your stuff to look like trash. Make it good then it won't be bad. It's probably important that images look okay here by default as well: Contrary to popular belief, Lorem Ipsum is not simply random text. It has roots in a piece of classical Latin literature from 45 BC, making it over 2000 years old. Now I'm going to show you an example of an unordered list to make sure that looks good, too: - So here is the first item in this list. - In this example we're keeping the items short. - Later, we'll use longer, more complex list items. And that's the end of this section. ## What if we stack headings? ### We should make sure that looks good, too. Sometimes you have headings directly underneath each other. In those cases you often have to undo the top margin on the second heading because it usually looks better for the headings to be closer together than a paragraph followed by a heading should be. ### When a heading comes after a paragraph … When a heading comes after a paragraph, we need a bit more space, like I already mentioned above. Now let's see what a more complex list would look like. - **I often do this thing where list items have headings.** For some reason I think this looks cool which is unfortunate because it's pretty annoying to get the styles right. I often have two or three paragraphs in these list items, too, so the hard part is getting the spacing between the paragraphs, list item heading, and separate list items to all make sense. Pretty tough honestly, you could make a strong argument that you just shouldn't write this way. - **Since this is a list, I need at least two items.** I explained what I'm doing already in the previous list item, but a list wouldn't be a list if it only had one item, and we really want this to look realistic. That's why I've added this second list item so I actually have something to look at when writing the styles. - **It's not a bad idea to add a third item either.** I think it probably would've been fine to just use two items but three is definitely not worse, and since I seem to be having no trouble making up arbitrary things to type, I might as well include it. After this sort of list I usually have a closing statement or paragraph, because it kinda looks weird jumping right to a heading. ## Code should look okay by default. I think most people are going to use [highlight.js](https://highlightjs.org/) or [Prism](https://prismjs.com/) or something if they want to style their code blocks but it wouldn't hurt to make them look _okay_ out of the box, even with no syntax highlighting. Here's what a default `tailwind.config.js` file looks like at the time of writing: ```js module.exports = { purge: [], theme: { extend: {}, }, variants: {}, plugins: [], } ``` Hopefully that looks good enough to you. ### What about nested lists? Nested lists basically always look bad which is why editors like Medium don't even let you do it, but I guess since some of you goofballs are going to do it we have to carry the burden of at least making it work. 1. **Nested lists are rarely a good idea.** - You might feel like you are being really "organized" or something but you are just creating a gross shape on the screen that is hard to read. - Nested navigation in UIs is a bad idea too, keep things as flat as possible. - Nesting tons of folders in your source code is also not helpful. 2. **Since we need to have more items, here's another one.** - I'm not sure if we'll bother styling more than two levels deep. - Two is already too much, three is guaranteed to be a bad idea. - If you nest four levels deep you belong in prison. 3. **Two items isn't really a list, three is good though.** - Again please don't nest lists if you want people to actually read your content. - Nobody wants to look at this. - I'm upset that we even have to bother styling this. The most annoying thing about lists in Markdown is that `
  • ` elements aren't given a child `

    ` tag unless there are multiple paragraphs in the list item. That means I have to worry about styling that annoying situation too. - **For example, here's another nested list.** But this time with a second paragraph. - These list items won't have `

    ` tags - Because they are only one line each - **But in this second top-level list item, they will.** This is especially annoying because of the spacing on this paragraph. - As you can see here, because I've added a second line, this list item now has a `

    ` tag. This is the second line I'm talking about by the way. - Finally here's another list item so it's more like a list. - A closing list item, but with no nested list, because why not? And finally a sentence to close off this section. ## There are other elements we need to style I almost forgot to mention links, like [this link to the Tailwind CSS website](https://tailwindcss.com). We almost made them blue but that's so yesterday, so we went with dark gray, feels edgier. We even included table styles, check it out: We also need to make sure inline code looks good, like if I wanted to talk about `` elements or tell you the good news about `@tailwindcss/typography`. ### Sometimes I even use `code` in headings Even though it's probably a bad idea, and historically I've had a hard time making it look good. This _"wrap the code blocks in backticks"_ trick works pretty well though really. Another thing I've done in the past is put a `code` tag inside of a link, like if I wanted to tell you about the [`tailwindcss/docs`](https://github.com/tailwindcss/docs) repository. I don't love that there is an underline below the backticks but it is absolutely not worth the madness it would require to avoid it. #### We haven't used an `h4` yet But now we have. Please don't use `h5` or `h6` in your content, Medium only supports two heading levels for a reason, you animals. I honestly considered using a `before` pseudo-element to scream at you if you use an `h5` or `h6`. We don't style them at all out of the box because `h4` elements are already so small that they are the same size as the body copy. What are we supposed to do with an `h5`, make it _smaller_ than the body copy? No thanks. ### We still need to think about stacked headings though. #### Let's make sure we don't screw that up with `h4` elements, either. Phew, with any luck we have styled the headings above this text and they look pretty good. Let's add a closing paragraph here so things end with a decently sized block of text. I can't explain why I want things to end that way but I have to assume it's because I think things will look weird or unbalanced if there is a heading too close to the end of the document. What I've written here is probably long enough, but adding this final sentence can't hurt. ## GitHub Flavored Markdown I've also added support for GitHub Flavored Mardown using `remark-gfm`. With `remark-gfm`, we get a few extra features in our markdown. Example: autolink literals. A link like www.example.com or https://example.com would automatically be converted into an `a` tag. This works for email links too: contact@example.com.

Garlic bread with cheese: What the science tells us

For years parents have espoused the health benefits of eating garlic bread with cheese to their children, with the food earning such an iconic status in our culture that kids will often dress up as warm, cheesy loaf for Halloween.

But a recent study shows that the celebrated appetizer may be linked to a series of rabies cases springing up around the country.
